column4: While installing ubuntu I forgot to partition a swap drive, is there a way to fix this without reformating the drive?
you can add a swap file
you'll need to create an empty file, the size you want for your swap, then format that file for swap, put an entry in fstab for it, and then run swapon on that file
I can walk you through it
how much swap space do you want?
OK, first off: create the file. run "sudo dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=512"
that will create an empty file 512 megs in size
just let me know when you're done with that step.
it's ok. Now, you need to format it. "sudo mkswap /swapfile"
Congratulations, you now have 512 megs of swap. Now, we need to make it permanent.
once that's open you should see a bunch of lines describing your filesystems.
add a NEW LINE at the end of the file, as follows: "/swapfile none swap sw 0 1" (without the quotes of course)
then hit ctrl-x to quit, and when prompted, save the file
OK. If you want to check that it works, you can reboot, and once rebooted, running the command "free" should show you 512 megs of swap space.
if it doesn't show up, your fstab line may be wrong
Let me know how that goes.
